image.altText: Two people sit in hot springs water surrounded by steam and sand

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal a sacred women's site in the Northern Territory has been impacted by government infrastructure at a popular tourist hot spring.

title.children: Sacred site at popular NT hot springs impacted by government-constructed bore

image.altText: A young woman is on the shoulders of a man in a march. She's holding an Aboriginal flag

items.synopsis: For years, political parties from across the divide have failed equally at bettering the lot of people in the Northern Territory. How will the NT ever see substantive change?

title.children: A ‘failed state’ or a ‘political football’? Australia must face up to the reality of the Northern Territory

image.altText: A man wearing a pale blue business shirt and navy tie walks with a stern expression.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for Zachary Rolfe have asked the Northern Territory coroner to "consider recusing herself" from an inquest into the death of Kumanjayi Walker "on the grounds of apprehended bias".

title.children: Zachary Rolfe asks NT coroner to consider stepping aside from Kumanjayi Walker inquest

image.altText: Composite image of Natasha Wanganeen and James Stevens

items.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price was not on ABC's Q+A but a colleague's defence of her comments on colonisation drew a heated response as the Voice referendum looms large.

title.children: 'Disgusting language': Heated clash over colonisation and Jacinta Price dominates Q+A

image.altText: A police officer stands on a road in front of a police vehicle within a park

items.synopsis: Emergency services were called to the scene at 1pm on Sunday following reports two people had been struck by a large tree branch.

title.children: Woman killed by falling tree branch in Darwin a South African national, police say

image.altText: A close-up photo of John Howard pointing to an audience, with Australian flags in the background

items.synopsis: Former prime minister John Howard says the Northern Territory government has failed to provide adequate police, health and education services in the 15 years since the Intervention. But a political expert has labelled those comments a "partisan swipe".

title.children: John Howard's criticism of the NT government dismissed as political 'point-scoring'

image.altText: A woman with pink hair hands out info at a pre-polling station

items.synopsis: More people are undecided on the Voice to Parliament than during the last federal election. But is there enough to sway the outcome either way?

title.children: Female, middle-aged and left-leaning: Meet the people most likely to be undecided on the Voice

image.altText: A woman holds her head in her hand as she openly sobbed, while another woman consoles her

items.synopsis: Hamas has held Israeli civilians and soldiers captive before, but history shows this hostage situation could be much more difficult for Israel to resolve.

title.children: From festivalgoers to children and grandmothers: Inside the hostage crisis orchestrated by Hamas

image.altText: Clinical nurse Nat Karmichael stands with arms crossed looking at camera

items.synopsis: Patients with severe mental illness are having to sleep on the floor or couches inside Queensland's largest hospital due to chronic bed shortages, with some left waiting days.

title.children: Mental health patients left to sleep on the floor and couches due to chronic bed shortages at Queensland's largest hospital

image.altText: Palestinians inspect the rubble of the West mosque destroyed after it was hit by an Israeli airstrike.

items.synopsis: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vows to "change the Middle East" while Hamas threatens to broadcast the execution of captives in return for every Israeli bombing of a civilian house without warning.

title.children: Netanyahu vows to 'change the Middle East' in show of force against Hamas as Hezbollah fires rockets from Lebanon

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a black jacket sits against a dark background.

items.synopsis: They were one of the biggest bands of the 90s, ended by a bitter sibling rivalry. But almost three decades on, Noel Gallagher says the glory days of Oasis were everything he had hoped they would ever be.

title.children: Noel Gallagher on the highs of Oasis and the feud with Liam that ended the band

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit with glasses and slicked-back hair stands in front of the red tail of a Qantas plane.

items.synopsis: Qantas may well be an extreme example of the greed and hubris that is endemic in the corporate world, but it is far from alone, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The Qantas flame-out is a symptom of something much more serious

image.altText: Global Lithium rock

items.synopsis: The race towards to a clean energy future is driving a momentous increase in demand for critical minerals. But just what those minerals are in Australia is up for debate — and it will have a major impact on the future of life as we know it.

title.children: It looks like any ordinary rock in outback Australia, but what's inside holds the key to our clean energy future

image.altText: A young woman in a softly lit room holds a glowing plastic toy.

items.synopsis: Live streaming has become a multi-billion-dollar industry, as people pay to watch everything from someone sleeping to them eating chips. So what's the appeal?

title.children: Trish works as a full-time live streamer. Here's why thousands tune in

image.altText: Rockets in the sky over the city of Ashkelon.

items.synopsis: Israel's Iron Dome air defence system is reputed to be the most sophisticated in the world, but experts say it became overwhelmed during Hamas's unprecedented assault. Did it fail and what more can it withstand?

title.children: Israel's Iron Dome was 'overwhelmed' in the Hamas attack. What happens if Hezbollah gets involved?

image.altText: flares were let off at a pro-palestine rally on the opera house forecourt on monday october 9

items.synopsis: Flares and fireworks were lit in the crowd and thrown onto the forecourt steps of the Opera House, where rows of police officers were monitoring the situation.

title.children: 'Does not represent the people of NSW': Premier condemns rally after Sydney Opera House lit up in Israeli colours

image.altText: Former NT politician Shane Stone looking serious while standing in front of NT Parliament House.

items.synopsis: Shane Stone is elected unopposed by the Country Liberal Party’s rank-and-file as president, 10 months out from the next territory election.

title.children: Ex-NT chief minister elected as new Country Liberal Party president as election race ramps up

image.altText: Qatar Airways and Qantas planes on tarmac in Perth.

items.synopsis: The Senate committee examining the decision delivers its final report, making 10 recommendations, including that the government immediately review its decision.

title.children: 'Immediate action' needed to investigate government's Qatar Airways flight decision, committee finds

image.altText: Tom Robinson with parents at Brisbane Airport

items.synopsis: Everyone at Brisbane Airport was eager to hear how Tom Robinson is faring following his brush with death, but his only focus now is family.

title.children: 'Good to be alive': Rower rescued from flipped vessel in Pacific Ocean returns home

image.altText: A grey-haired man wears a transparent eyepatch on his left eye.

items.synopsis: Shannon Davis was declared legally blind due to end-stage glaucoma at 43, despite reporting no symptoms beforehand. He's now calling for more awareness of and testing for the disease, which is known as "the silent thief of sight".

title.children: 'The silent thief of sight': At 43 and despite reporting no symptoms, Shannon was declared legally blind

image.altText: Two separate corflutes on an iron gate read 'VOTE NO' and 'VOTE YES'.

items.synopsis: Tasmania's Liberal premier is urging a Yes vote in Saturday's referendum but the dominant Indigenous group says No. What is happening on the island state and why do polls say it is the only state tracking in favour?

title.children: Why is Tasmania the only state leaning towards a Yes vote in the referendum?

image.altText: Falcon with feathers poking out of it sits on the edge of a high-rise building ledge.

items.synopsis: The falcons have been laying eggs on the top of the 34-storey building since 1991, but this year, there won't be hatchlings.

title.children: Sadness for Melbourne's high-rise falcon family as eggs deemed not viable

image.altText: Man wearing a cap stands in front of garage door

items.synopsis: Finding a storage container to keep belongings in while sleeping in his car, was almost as expensive as rent, according to Mark Lovett, who feared he would be homeless after his unit was removed from the National Rental Affordability Scheme.

title.children: 'Nothing I'd ever experienced in my life': Paying for storage after losing his rental left Mark facing homelessness

image.altText: A young woman with short copper hair leaning on a fence post. She is wearing a black shirt

items.synopsis: After more than a year of gruelling treatments for melanoma, she is now raising awareness about the prevalence of the disease among young people.

title.children: At just 19, Crystal thought her itchy spot was harmless. Then she went for a skin check

image.altText: Two boys and a man stand in front of a dirt jump BMX track

items.synopsis: Building trails, jumps and ramps out of dirt might be a nuisance for councils, but it's a source of pride for many young BMX riders. Riders and researchers want local governments to back the pastime of building tracks in approved places.

title.children: There's more to building BMX tracks than just digging. There's what a researcher says

image.altText: A smiling young girl in headshot

items.synopsis: The parents of Aishwarya Aswath, who died while waiting for treatment at Perth Children's Hospital, say a royal commission is needed to ensure transparency following the alleged rape of a teenager at the same facility.

title.children: Parents of 7yo girl who died at children's hospital renew calls for royal commission following alleged rape

image.altText: A photo of a middle-aged woman sits to the left of a blue slide with white writing and a golden Nobel insignia.

items.synopsis: It follows the official Nobel Prizes in medicine, physics, chemistry, literature and peace that were announced last week.

title.children: Harvard professor Claudia Goldin awarded Nobel economics prize for work on labour market gender gap

image.altText: An oil pump sits idle against an orange sky.

items.synopsis: The conflict between Hamas and Israel has coincided with an oil supply shortage and led to a massive spike in the price of crude oil.

title.children: ‘Very worrying’: Motorists should brace for a surge in petrol prices and higher interest rates, analysts warn

image.altText: Smoke rises above apartment buildings.

items.synopsis: The situation in Israel is unpredictable and changing quickly, but one of the few certainties is that Israel will respond ferociously. This crisis is almost certain to get much worse before it gets better, writes John Lyons.

title.children: The Hamas attack creates a dilemma for Israel, which is facing its most serious crisis in decades

image.altText: A shirtless man with dreadlocks leans on a van in the desert and plays a guitar.

items.synopsis: A coroner finds that Travis Cashmore intentionally shot two men and drove over their bodies with his van before taking his life in Victoria last year.

title.children: A lottery ticket and a smile led up to double murder, shooter's death, inquest confirms

image.altText: the premier of new south wales chris minns talking to the media outdoors

items.synopsis: The Minns government said it would introduce a bill to parliament this week, in an effort to reduce long-term drug offending.

title.children: New drug laws in NSW to see people fined for minor possession, avoiding criminal conviction

image.altText: A black and white photograph of a man with square framed glasses and short grey hair.

items.synopsis: David Richards must not have contact with female patients or work outside the Gold Coast where clinic he is based, under conditions imposed by the Health Ombudsman.

title.children: Gold Coast doctor banned from contact with female patients

image.altText: Brian Mendoza

items.synopsis: American Brian Mendoza talks up his firepower as Australian Tim Tszyu puts his super-welterweight belt on the line at the Gold Coast this Sunday.

title.children: 'I'll hurt you for 12 rounds': American takes aim at Tszyu ahead of Sunday's fight on the Gold Coast
